contentrichtext.text: {{For|the ternary "if" operator in C-like languages|?:}} In [[mathematics]], a '''ternary operation''' is an [[n-ary|''n''-ary]] [[Operation (mathematics)|operation]] with ''n'' = 3. A ternary operation on a set A takes any given three elements of A and combines them to form a single element of A. An example of a ternary operation is the product in a [[heap (mathematics)|heap]]. In [[computer science]], a '''ternary operator''' (sometimes incorrectly called a ''tertiary operator'') is an [[Operator (programming)|operator]] that takes three arguments. The arguments and result can be of different types. Many programming languages that use [[C syntax|C-like syntax]] feature a ternary operator, <code>[[?:]]</code>, which defines a [[conditional (programming)#If expressions|conditional expression]]. Since this operator is often the only existing ternary operator in the language, it is sometimes simply referred to as "''the'' ternary operator".
